questionTitle: My friends accusing me of having problems
questionText: They're calling me names like hypocrite and a baby even when they act in the same manner as I do. I'm tired of being called names. What should I do?
answerText: It sounds like your confused as to why your friends would be calling you a hypocrite when they act in the same manner, correct? Communication is key to any relationship. I would recommend speaking with your friends face-to-face to address why they feel your behavior is concerning. In-person contact is the best method of sorting out differences considering texts, emails or any written response can be misconstrued. Be upfront with them and let them know that being accused of hypocrisy is hurtful and you feel it is unfounded. If after speaking with them you feel that they have valid reasons for the way they are feeling, maybe you can consider modifying your behavior accordingly. Especially if this friendship is valuable to you. However, make sure they are aware that there is a respectful way to address these issues and name calling is not one of them. On the other hand, if you feel that their reasons are indeed unfounded, it may be best to distance yourself from the relationship. Not all friendships are healthy ones. And it is important that you surround yourself with people who are an asset to your self esteem as opposed to those that hinder it.I hope you are able to get this matter sorted. Best of luck!

questionTitle: How would I know if I have the right therapist?
questionText:
How do you know you have the right therapist for you?
 How would I know how to "train" my therapist to be able to give me what I need from treatment?
answerText: Finding the right therapist for you is very important and can sometimes be tricky. It can sometimes take a number of sessions to get a good sense of whether you and your therapist are the "right fit."  The first couple of sessions are generally spent on gathering information, formulating a plan of treatment, and building the client/therapist relationship. The client/therapist relationship will be very different from other relationships you have experienced.  You will know you have found the right therapist when you notice there is a good rapport between the two of you.  You will get a sense that the therapist "gets you" and understands the issues being presented. If you feel that you can trust your therapist and feel comfortable opening up and providing feedback during your sessions then you know it is a good fit. In terms of "how to train your therapist how to give you what you need from treatment" the therapeutic relationship is collaborative so the two of you will be working together as a team. During your sessions, the goal is for you to feel comfortable giving feedback about what is working and what is not working in your sessions. When you express your needs to your therapist then the two of you will discuss the best ways to get those needs met in order to maximize the effectiveness of your sessions.

2. Expertise and training: Does your therapist have the necessary education, training, and experience to treat your specific concerns? Make sure they have experience working with clients with concerns similar to yours.

5. Comfort with the therapeutic process: Are you comfortable with the therapeutic process and the techniques your therapist uses? It's important to feel comfortable with the approach your therapist is using.
6. Personal values and compatibility: Do you feel like your therapist's values and approach align with yours? It's important to find a therapist who you feel comfortable with and who you can work well with.

As for "training" your therapist, it's important to remember that therapists are trained professionals who are there to help you. While it's okay to communicate your needs and expectations to your therapist, it's not necessary

questionTitle: Is it normal to cry at therapy?
questionText: Is it normal for people to cry during therapy, or is it just me?
answerText: It's more than just normal, it's expected! Quite honestly, there are a very few days where at least one client hasn't cried during therapy throughout the day. -IJP

###User: Is it normal for people to cry during therapy, or is it just me?###You: [/INST]  Thank you for asking! It's completely normal for people to feel emotional and tearful during therapy sessions. Therapy is a safe and supportive space for individuals to process and express their emotions, and it's common for people to experience a range of emotions, including sadness, anger, and relief.

It's important to remember that therapy is not just about "fixing" problems, but also about creating a space for individuals to explore and understand their emotions and experiences. Tears can be a natural response to the emotional release that can occur during therapy, and they do not necessarily indicate that someone is "broken" or "crazy."

In fact, research has shown that emotional expression and release can be beneficial for mental health and well-being. Tears can help individuals process and release emotions, and can also serve as a sign of emotional release and catharsis.

If you find yourself feeling emotional or tearful during therapy, it's important to communicate this to your therapist. They are trained to work with individuals who are experiencing a range of emotions, and they can help you process and support you through your emotions.

Remember, therapy is a safe and supportive space for you to explore and express your emotions, and it's completely normal to feel emotional during these sessions. Don't be afraid to communicate your feelings to your therapist, and know that they are there to support you every step of the way.
